title: NMCapability
description: NMCapability names the numbers in the Capabilities property. Capabilities are positive numbers. They are part of stable API and a certain capability number is guaranteed not to change.

items.label: NM_CAPABILITY_TEAM
items.desc: Teams can be managed. This means the team device plugin is loaded.

items.label: NM_CAPABILITY_OVS
items.desc: OpenVSwitch can be managed. This means the OVS device plugin is loaded. Since: 1.24

title: NMState
description: NMState values indicate the current overall networking state.

items.label: NM_STATE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: Networking state is unknown. This indicates a daemon error that makes it unable to reasonably assess the state. In such event the applications are expected to assume Internet connectivity might be present and not disable controls that require network access. The graphical shells may hide the network accessibility indicator altogether since no meaningful status indication can be provided.

items.label: NM_STATE_ASLEEP
items.desc: Networking is not enabled, the system is being suspended or resumed from suspend.

items.label: NM_STATE_DISCONNECTED
items.desc: There is no active network connection. The graphical shell should indicate  no network connectivity and the applications should not attempt to access the network.

items.label: NM_STATE_DISCONNECTING
items.desc: Network connections are being cleaned up. The applications should tear down their network sessions.

items.label: NM_STATE_CONNECTING
items.desc: A network connection is being started The graphical shell should indicate the network is being connected while the applications should still make no attempts to connect the network.

items.label: NM_STATE_CONNECTED_LOCAL
items.desc: There is only local IPv4 and/or IPv6 connectivity, but no default route to access the Internet. The graphical shell should indicate no network connectivity.

items.label: NM_STATE_CONNECTED_SITE
items.desc: There is only site-wide IPv4 and/or IPv6 connectivity. This means a default route is available, but the Internet connectivity check (see "Connectivity" property) did not succeed. The graphical shell should indicate limited network connectivity.

items.label: NM_STATE_CONNECTED_GLOBAL
items.desc: There is global IPv4 and/or IPv6 Internet connectivity This means the Internet connectivity check succeeded, the graphical shell should indicate full network connectivity.

items.label: NM_CONNECTIVITY_UNKNOWN
items.desc: Network connectivity is unknown. This means the connectivity checks are disabled (e.g. on server installations) or has not run yet. The graphical shell should assume the Internet connection might be available and not present a captive portal window.

items.label: NM_CONNECTIVITY_NONE
items.desc: The host is not connected to any network. There's no active connection that contains a default route to the internet and thus it makes no sense to even attempt a connectivity check. The graphical shell should use this state to indicate the network connection is unavailable.

items.label: NM_CONNECTIVITY_PORTAL
items.desc: The Internet connection is hijacked by a captive portal gateway. The graphical shell may open a sandboxed web browser window (because the captive portals typically attempt a man-in-the-middle attacks against the https connections) for the purpose of authenticating to a gateway and retrigger the connectivity check with CheckConnectivity() when the browser window is dismissed.

items.label: NM_CONNECTIVITY_LIMITED
items.desc: The host is connected to a network, does not appear to be able to reach the full Internet, but a captive portal has not been detected.

items.label: NM_CONNECTIVITY_FULL
items.desc: The host is connected to a network, and appears to be able to reach the full Internet.

title: NMDeviceType
description: NMDeviceType values indicate the type of hardware represented by a device object.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: unknown device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_GENERIC
items.desc: generic support for unrecognized device types

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_ETHERNET
items.desc: a wired ethernet device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIFI
items.desc: an 802.11 Wi-Fi device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_UNUSED1
items.desc: not used

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_UNUSED2
items.desc: not used

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_BT
items.desc: a Bluetooth device supporting PAN or DUN access protocols

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OLPC_MESH
items.desc: an OLPC XO mesh networking device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIMAX
items.desc: an 802.16e Mobile WiMAX broadband device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_MODEM
items.desc: a modem supporting analog telephone, CDMA/EVDO, GSM/UMTS, or LTE network access protocols

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_INFINIBAND
items.desc: an IP-over-InfiniBand device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_BOND
items.desc: a bond master interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VLAN
items.desc: an 802.1Q VLAN interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_ADSL
items.desc: ADSL modem

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_BRIDGE
items.desc: a bridge master interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_TEAM
items.desc: a team master interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_TUN
items.desc: a TUN or TAP interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_IP_TUNNEL
items.desc: a IP tunnel interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_MACVLAN
items.desc: a MACVLAN interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VXLAN
items.desc: a VXLAN interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VETH
items.desc: a VETH interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_MACSEC
items.desc: a MACsec interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_DUMMY
items.desc: a dummy interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_PPP
items.desc: a PPP interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OVS_INTERFACE
items.desc: a Open vSwitch interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OVS_PORT
items.desc: a Open vSwitch port

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OVS_BRIDGE
items.desc: a Open vSwitch bridge

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WPAN
items.desc: a IEEE 802.15.4 (WPAN) MAC Layer Device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_6LOWPAN
items.desc: 6LoWPAN interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIREGUARD
items.desc: a WireGuard interface

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIFI_P2P
items.desc: an 802.11 Wi-Fi P2P device (Since: 1.16)

items.label: NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VRF
items.desc: A VRF (Virtual Routing and Forwarding) interface (Since: 1.24)

title: NMDeviceCapabilities
description: General device capability flags.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_CAP_NONE
items.desc: device has no special capabilities

items.label: NM_DEVICE_CAP_NM_SUPPORTED
items.desc: NetworkManager supports this device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_CAP_CARRIER_DETECT
items.desc: this device can indicate carrier status

items.label: NM_DEVICE_CAP_IS_SOFTWARE
items.desc: this device is a software device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_CAP_SRIOV
items.desc: this device supports single-root I/O virtualization

title: NMDeviceWifiCapabilities
description: 802.11 specific device encryption and authentication capabilities.

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_NONE
items.desc: device has no encryption/authentication capabilities

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_CIPHER_WEP40
items.desc: device supports 40/64-bit WEP encryption

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_CIPHER_WEP104
items.desc: device supports 104/128-bit WEP encryption

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_CIPHER_TKIP
items.desc: device supports TKIP encryption

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_CIPHER_CCMP
items.desc: device supports AES/CCMP encryption

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_WPA
items.desc: device supports WPA1 authentication

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_RSN
items.desc: device supports WPA2/RSN authentication

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_AP
items.desc: device supports Access Point mode

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_ADHOC
items.desc: device supports Ad-Hoc mode

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_FREQ_VALID
items.desc: device reports frequency capabilities

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_FREQ_2GHZ
items.desc: device supports 2.4GHz frequencies

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_FREQ_5GHZ
items.desc: device supports 5GHz frequencies

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_MESH
items.desc: device supports acting as a mesh point. Since: 1.20.

items.label: NM_WIFI_DEVICE_CAP_IBSS_RSN
items.desc: device supports WPA2/RSN in an IBSS network. Since: 1.22.

title: NM80211ApFlags
description: 802.11 access point flags.

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_FLAGS_NONE
items.desc: access point has no special capabilities

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_FLAGS_PRIVACY
items.desc: access point requires authentication and encryption (usually means WEP)

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_FLAGS_WPS
items.desc: access point supports some WPS method

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_FLAGS_WPS_PBC
items.desc: access point supports push-button WPS

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_FLAGS_WPS_PIN
items.desc: access point supports PIN-based WPS

title: NM80211ApSecurityFlags
description: 802.11 access point security and authentication flags.  These flags describe the current security requirements of an access point as determined from the access point's beacon.

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_NONE
items.desc: the access point has no special security requirements

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_PAIR_WEP40
items.desc: 40/64-bit WEP is supported for pairwise/unicast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_PAIR_WEP104
items.desc: 104/128-bit WEP is supported for pairwise/unicast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_PAIR_TKIP
items.desc: TKIP is supported for pairwise/unicast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_PAIR_CCMP
items.desc: AES/CCMP is supported for pairwise/unicast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_GROUP_WEP40
items.desc: 40/64-bit WEP is supported for group/broadcast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_GROUP_WEP104
items.desc: 104/128-bit WEP is supported for group/broadcast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_GROUP_TKIP
items.desc: TKIP is supported for group/broadcast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_GROUP_CCMP
items.desc: AES/CCMP is supported for group/broadcast encryption

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_KEY_MGMT_PSK
items.desc: WPA/RSN Pre-Shared Key encryption is supported

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_KEY_MGMT_802_1X
items.desc: 802.1x authentication and key management is supported

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_KEY_MGMT_SAE
items.desc: WPA/RSN Simultaneous Authentication of Equals is supported

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_KEY_MGMT_OWE
items.desc: WPA/RSN Opportunistic Wireless Encryption is supported

items.label: NM_802_11_AP_SEC_KEY_MGMT_OWE_TM
items.desc: WPA/RSN Opportunistic Wireless Encryption transition mode is supported. Since: 1.26.

title: NM80211Mode
description: Indicates the 802.11 mode an access point or device is currently in.

items.label: NM_802_11_MODE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: the device or access point mode is unknown

items.label: NM_802_11_MODE_ADHOC
items.desc: for both devices and access point objects, indicates the object is part of an Ad-Hoc 802.11 network without a central coordinating access point.

items.label: NM_802_11_MODE_INFRA
items.desc: the device or access point is in infrastructure mode. For devices, this indicates the device is an 802.11 client/station.  For access point objects, this indicates the object is an access point that provides connectivity to clients.

items.label: NM_802_11_MODE_AP
items.desc: the device is an access point/hotspot.  Not valid for access point objects; used only for hotspot mode on the local machine.

items.label: NM_802_11_MODE_MESH
items.desc: the device is a 802.11s mesh point. Since: 1.20.

title: NMBluetoothCapabilities
description: NMBluetoothCapabilities values indicate the usable capabilities of a Bluetooth device.

items.label: NM_BT_CAPABILITY_NONE
items.desc: device has no usable capabilities

items.label: NM_BT_CAPABILITY_DUN
items.desc: device provides Dial-Up Networking capability

items.label: NM_BT_CAPABILITY_NAP
items.desc: device provides Network Access Point capability

title: NMDeviceModemCapabilities
description: NMDeviceModemCapabilities values indicate the generic radio access technology families a modem device supports.  For more information on the specific access technologies the device supports use the ModemManager D-Bus API.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_MODEM_CAPABILITY_NONE
items.desc: modem has no usable capabilities

items.label: NM_DEVICE_MODEM_CAPABILITY_POTS
items.desc: modem uses the analog wired telephone network and is not a wireless/cellular device

items.label: NM_DEVICE_MODEM_CAPABILITY_CDMA_EVDO
items.desc: modem supports at least one of CDMA 1xRTT, EVDO revision 0, EVDO revision A, or EVDO revision B

items.label: NM_DEVICE_MODEM_CAPABILITY_GSM_UMTS
items.desc: modem supports at least one of GSM, GPRS, EDGE, UMTS, HSDPA, HSUPA, or HSPA+ packet switched data capability

items.label: NM_DEVICE_MODEM_CAPABILITY_LTE
items.desc: modem has LTE data capability

title: NMWimaxNspNetworkType
description: WiMAX network type.

items.label: NM_WIMAX_NSP_NETWORK_TYPE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: unknown network type

items.label: NM_WIMAX_NSP_NETWORK_TYPE_HOME
items.desc: home network

items.label: NM_WIMAX_NSP_NETWORK_TYPE_PARTNER
items.desc: partner network

items.label: NM_WIMAX_NSP_NETWORK_TYPE_ROAMING_PARTNER
items.desc: roaming partner network

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: the device's state is unknown

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_UNMANAGED
items.desc: the device is recognized, but not managed by NetworkManager

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_UNAVAILABLE
items.desc: the device is managed by NetworkManager, but is not available for use.  Reasons may include the wireless switched off, missing firmware, no ethernet carrier, missing supplicant or modem manager, etc.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_DISCONNECTED
items.desc: the device can be activated, but is currently idle and not connected to a network.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_PREPARE
items.desc: the device is preparing the connection to the network.  This may include operations like changing the MAC address, setting physical link properties, and anything else required to connect to the requested network.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_CONFIG
items.desc: the device is connecting to the requested network. This may include operations like associating with the Wi-Fi AP, dialing the modem, connecting to the remote Bluetooth device, etc.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_NEED_AUTH
items.desc: the device requires more information to continue connecting to the requested network.  This includes secrets like WiFi passphrases, login passwords, PIN codes, etc.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_IP_CONFIG
items.desc: the device is requesting IPv4 and/or IPv6 addresses and routing information from the network.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_IP_CHECK
items.desc: the device is checking whether further action is required for the requested network connection.  This may include checking whether only local network access is available, whether a captive portal is blocking access to the Internet, etc.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_SECONDARIES
items.desc: the device is waiting for a secondary connection (like a VPN) which must activated before the device can be activated

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_ACTIVATED
items.desc: the device has a network connection, either local or global.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_DEACTIVATING
items.desc: a disconnection from the current network connection was requested, and the device is cleaning up resources used for that connection.  The network connection may still be valid.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_FAILED
items.desc: the device failed to connect to the requested network and is cleaning up the connection request

title: NMDeviceStateReason
description: Device state change reason codes

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_NONE
items.desc: No reason given

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_UNKNOWN
items.desc: Unknown error

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_NOW_MANAGED
items.desc: Device is now managed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_NOW_UNMANAGED
items.desc: Device is now unmanaged

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_CONFIG_FAILED
items.desc: The device could not be readied for configuration

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_IP_CONFIG_UNAVAILABLE
items.desc: IP configuration could not be reserved (no available address, timeout, etc)

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_IP_CONFIG_EXPIRED
items.desc: The IP config is no longer valid

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_NO_SECRETS
items.desc: Secrets were required, but not provided

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SUPPLICANT_DISCONNECT
items.desc: 802.1x supplicant disconnected

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SUPPLICANT_CONFIG_FAILED
items.desc: 802.1x supplicant configuration failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SUPPLICANT_FAILED
items.desc: 802.1x supplicant failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SUPPLICANT_TIMEOUT
items.desc: 802.1x supplicant took too long to authenticate

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_PPP_START_FAILED
items.desc: PPP service failed to start

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_PPP_DISCONNECT
items.desc: PPP service disconnected

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_PPP_FAILED
items.desc: PPP failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_DHCP_START_FAILED
items.desc: DHCP client failed to start

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_DHCP_ERROR
items.desc: DHCP client error

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_DHCP_FAILED
items.desc: DHCP client failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SHARED_START_FAILED
items.desc: Shared connection service failed to start

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SHARED_FAILED
items.desc: Shared connection service failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_AUTOIP_START_FAILED
items.desc: AutoIP service failed to start

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_AUTOIP_ERROR
items.desc: AutoIP service error

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_AUTOIP_FAILED
items.desc: AutoIP service failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_BUSY
items.desc: The line is busy

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_NO_DIAL_TONE
items.desc: No dial tone

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_NO_CARRIER
items.desc: No carrier could be established

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_DIAL_TIMEOUT
items.desc: The dialing request timed out

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_DIAL_FAILED
items.desc: The dialing attempt failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_INIT_FAILED
items.desc: Modem initialization failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_APN_FAILED
items.desc: Failed to select the specified APN

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_REGISTRATION_NOT_SEARCHING
items.desc: Not searching for networks

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_REGISTRATION_DENIED
items.desc: Network registration denied

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_REGISTRATION_TIMEOUT
items.desc: Network registration timed out

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_REGISTRATION_FAILED
items.desc: Failed to register with the requested network

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_PIN_CHECK_FAILED
items.desc: PIN check failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_FIRMWARE_MISSING
items.desc: Necessary firmware for the device may be missing

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_REMOVED
items.desc: The device was removed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SLEEPING
items.desc: NetworkManager went to sleep

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_CONNECTION_REMOVED
items.desc: The device's active connection disappeared

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_USER_REQUESTED
items.desc: Device disconnected by user or client

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_CARRIER
items.desc: Carrier/link changed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_CONNECTION_ASSUMED
items.desc: The device's existing connection was assumed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SUPPLICANT_AVAILABLE
items.desc: The supplicant is now available

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_NOT_FOUND
items.desc: The modem could not be found

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_BT_FAILED
items.desc: The Bluetooth connection failed or timed out

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_SIM_NOT_INSERTED
items.desc: GSM Modem's SIM Card not inserted

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_SIM_PIN_REQUIRED
items.desc: GSM Modem's SIM Pin required

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_SIM_PUK_REQUIRED
items.desc: GSM Modem's SIM Puk required

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_GSM_SIM_WRONG
items.desc: GSM Modem's SIM wrong

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_INFINIBAND_MODE
items.desc: InfiniBand device does not support connected mode

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_DEPENDENCY_FAILED
items.desc: A dependency of the connection failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_BR2684_FAILED
items.desc: Problem with the RFC 2684 Ethernet over ADSL bridge

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_MANAGER_UNAVAILABLE
items.desc: ModemManager not running

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SSID_NOT_FOUND
items.desc: The Wi-Fi network could not be found

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SECONDARY_CONNECTION_FAILED
items.desc: A secondary connection of the base connection failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_DCB_FCOE_FAILED
items.desc: DCB or FCoE setup failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_TEAMD_CONTROL_FAILED
items.desc: teamd control failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_FAILED
items.desc: Modem failed or no longer available

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_MODEM_AVAILABLE
items.desc: Modem now ready and available

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SIM_PIN_INCORRECT
items.desc: SIM PIN was incorrect

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_NEW_ACTIVATION
items.desc: New connection activation was enqueued

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_PARENT_CHANGED
items.desc: the device's parent changed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_PARENT_MANAGED_CHANGED
items.desc: the device parent's management changed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_OVSDB_FAILED
items.desc: problem communicating with Open vSwitch database

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_IP_ADDRESS_DUPLICATE
items.desc: a duplicate IP address was detected

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_IP_METHOD_UNSUPPORTED
items.desc: The selected IP method is not supported

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_SRIOV_CONFIGURATION_FAILED
items.desc: configuration of SR-IOV parameters failed

items.label: NM_DEVICE_STATE_REASON_PEER_NOT_FOUND
items.desc: The Wi-Fi P2P peer could not be found

title: NMMetered
description: The NMMetered enum has two different purposes: one is to configure "connection.metered" setting of a connection profile in NMSettingConnection, and the other is to express the actual metered state of the NMDevice at a given moment.

items.label: NM_METERED_UNKNOWN
items.desc: The metered status is unknown

items.label: NM_METERED_YES
items.desc: Metered, the value was explicitly configured

items.label: NM_METERED_NO
items.desc: Not metered, the value was explicitly configured

items.label: NM_METERED_GUESS_YES
items.desc: Metered, the value was guessed

items.label: NM_METERED_GUESS_NO
items.desc: Not metered, the value was guessed

title: NMConnectionMultiConnect
description: Since: 1.14

items.label: NM_CONNECTION_MULTI_CONNECT_DEFAULT
items.desc: indicates that the per-connection setting is unspecified. In this case, it will fallback to the default value, which is %NM_CONNECTION_MULTI_CONNECT_SINGLE.

items.label: NM_CONNECTION_MULTI_CONNECT_SINGLE
items.desc: the connection profile can only be active once at each moment. Activating a profile that is already active, will first deactivate it.

items.label: NM_CONNECTION_MULTI_CONNECT_MANUAL_MULTIPLE
items.desc: the profile can be manually activated multiple times on different devices. However, regarding autoconnect, the profile will autoconnect only if it is currently not connected otherwise.

items.label: NM_CONNECTION_MULTI_CONNECT_MULTIPLE
items.desc: the profile can autoactivate and be manually activated multiple times together.

title: NMActiveConnectionState
description: NMActiveConnectionState values indicate the state of a connection to a specific network while it is starting, connected, or disconnecting from that network.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: the state of the connection is unknown

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_ACTIVATING
items.desc: a network connection is being prepared

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_ACTIVATED
items.desc: there is a connection to the network

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_DEACTIVATING
items.desc: the network connection is being torn down and cleaned up

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_DEACTIVATED
items.desc: the network connection is disconnected and will be removed

title: NMActiveConnectionStateReason
description: Active connection state reasons.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_UNKNOWN
items.desc: The reason for the active connection state change is unknown.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_NONE
items.desc: No reason was given for the active connection state change.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_USER_DISCONNECTED
items.desc: The active connection changed state because the user disconnected it.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_DEVICE_DISCONNECTED
items.desc: The active connection changed state because the device it was using was disconnected.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_SERVICE_STOPPED
items.desc: The service providing the VPN connection was stopped.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_IP_CONFIG_INVALID
items.desc: The IP config of the active connection was invalid.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_CONNECT_TIMEOUT
items.desc: The connection attempt to the VPN service timed out.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_SERVICE_START_TIMEOUT
items.desc: A timeout occurred while starting the service providing the VPN connection.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_SERVICE_START_FAILED
items.desc: Starting the service providing the VPN connection failed.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_NO_SECRETS
items.desc: Necessary secrets for the connection were not provided.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_LOGIN_FAILED
items.desc: Authentication to the server failed.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_CONNECTION_REMOVED
items.desc: The connection was deleted from settings.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_DEPENDENCY_FAILED
items.desc: Master connection of this connection failed to activate.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_DEVICE_REALIZE_FAILED
items.desc: Could not create the software device link.

items.label: NM_ACTIVE_CONNECTION_STATE_REASON_DEVICE_REMOVED
items.desc: The device this connection depended on disappeared.

title: NMSecretAgentGetSecretsFlags
description: NMSecretAgentGetSecretsFlags values modify the behavior of a GetSecrets request.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: no special behavior; by default no user interaction is allowed and requests for secrets are fulfilled from persistent storage, or if no secrets are available an error is returned.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_ALLOW_INTERACTION
items.desc: allows the request to interact with the user, possibly prompting via UI for secrets if any are required, or if none are found in persistent storage.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_REQUEST_NEW
items.desc: explicitly prompt for new secrets from the user.  This flag signals that NetworkManager thinks any existing secrets are invalid or wrong.  This flag implies that interaction is allowed.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_USER_REQUESTED
items.desc: set if the request was initiated by user-requested action via the D-Bus interface, as opposed to automatically initiated by NetworkManager in response to (for example) scan results or carrier changes.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_WPS_PBC_ACTIVE
items.desc: indicates that WPS enrollment is active with PBC method. The agent may suggest that the user pushes a button on the router instead of supplying a PSK.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_ONLY_SYSTEM
items.desc: Internal flag, not part of the D-Bus API.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_GET_SECRETS_FLAG_NO_ERRORS
items.desc: Internal flag, not part of the D-Bus API.

title: NMSecretAgentCapabilities
description: NMSecretAgentCapabilities indicate various capabilities of the agent.

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_CAPABILITY_NONE
items.desc: the agent supports no special capabilities

items.label: NM_SECRET_AGENT_CAPABILITY_VPN_HINTS
items.desc: the agent supports passing hints to VPN plugin authentication dialogs.

title: NMIPTunnelMode
description: The tunneling mode.

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_UNKNOWN
items.desc: Unknown/unset tunnel mode

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_IPIP
items.desc: IP in IP tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_GRE
items.desc: GRE tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_SIT
items.desc: SIT tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_ISATAP
items.desc: ISATAP tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_VTI
items.desc: VTI tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_IP6IP6
items.desc: IPv6 in IPv6 tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_IPIP6
items.desc: IPv4 in IPv6 tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_IP6GRE
items.desc: IPv6 GRE tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_VTI6
items.desc: IPv6 VTI tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_GRETAP
items.desc: GRETAP tunnel

items.label: NM_IP_TUNNEL_MODE_IP6GRETAP
items.desc: IPv6 GRETAP tunnel

title: NMCheckpointCreateFlags
description: The flags for CheckpointCreate call

items.label: NM_CHECKPOINT_CREATE_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: no flags

items.label: NM_CHECKPOINT_CREATE_FLAG_DESTROY_ALL
items.desc: when creating a new checkpoint, destroy all existing ones.

items.label: NM_CHECKPOINT_CREATE_FLAG_DELETE_NEW_CONNECTIONS
items.desc: upon rollback, delete any new connection added after the checkpoint (Since: 1.6)

items.label: NM_CHECKPOINT_CREATE_FLAG_DISCONNECT_NEW_DEVICES
items.desc: upon rollback, disconnect any new device appeared after the checkpoint (Since: 1.6)

items.label: NM_CHECKPOINT_CREATE_FLAG_ALLOW_OVERLAPPING
items.desc: by default, creating a checkpoint fails if there are already existing checkoints that reference the same devices. With this flag, creation of such checkpoints is allowed, however, if an older checkpoint that references overlapping devices gets rolled back, it will automatically destroy this checkpoint during rollback. This allows to create several overlapping checkpoints in parallel, and rollback to them at will. With the special case that rolling back to an older checkpoint will invalidate all overlapping younger checkpoints. This opts-in that the checkpoint can be automatically destroyed by the rollback of an older checkpoint. (Since: 1.12)

title: NMRollbackResult
description: The result of a checkpoint Rollback() operation for a specific device.

items.label: NM_ROLLBACK_RESULT_OK
items.desc: the rollback succeeded.

items.label: NM_ROLLBACK_RESULT_ERR_NO_DEVICE
items.desc: the device no longer exists.

items.label: NM_ROLLBACK_RESULT_ERR_DEVICE_UNMANAGED
items.desc: the device is now unmanaged.

items.label: NM_ROLLBACK_RESULT_ERR_FAILED
items.desc: other errors during rollback.

title: NMSettingsConnectionFlags
description: Flags describing the current activation state.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_CONNECTION_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: an alias for numeric zero, no flags set.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_CONNECTION_FLAG_UNSAVED
items.desc: the connection is not saved to disk. That either means, that the connection is in-memory only and currently is not backed by a file. Or, that the connection is backed by a file, but has modifications in-memory that were not persisted to disk.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_CONNECTION_FLAG_NM_GENERATED
items.desc: A connection is "nm-generated" if it was generated by NetworkManger. If the connection gets modified or saved by the user, the flag gets cleared. A nm-generated is also unsaved and has no backing file as it is in-memory only.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_CONNECTION_FLAG_VOLATILE
items.desc: The connection will be deleted when it disconnects. That is for in-memory connections (unsaved), which are currently active but deleted on disconnect. Volatile connections are always unsaved, but they are also no backing file on disk and are entirely in-memory only.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_CONNECTION_FLAG_EXTERNAL
items.desc: the profile was generated to represent an external configuration of a networking device. Since: 1.26

title: NMActivationStateFlags
description: Flags describing the current activation state.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: an alias for numeric zero, no flags set.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_IS_MASTER
items.desc: the device is a master.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_IS_SLAVE
items.desc: the device is a slave.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_LAYER2_READY
items.desc: layer2 is activated and ready.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_IP4_READY
items.desc: IPv4 setting is completed.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_IP6_READY
items.desc: IPv6 setting is completed.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_MASTER_HAS_SLAVES
items.desc: The master has any slave devices attached. This only makes sense if the device is a master.

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_LIFETIME_BOUND_TO_PROFILE_VISIBILITY
items.desc: the lifetime of the activation is bound to the visilibity of the connection profile, which in turn depends on "connection.permissions" and whether a session for the user exists. Since: 1.16

items.label: NM_ACTIVATION_STATE_FLAG_EXTERNAL
items.desc: the active connection was generated to represent an external configuration of a networking device. Since: 1.26

title: NMSettingsAddConnection2Flags
description: Numeric flags for the "flags" argument of AddConnection2() D-Bus API.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_ADD_CONNECTION2_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: an alias for numeric zero, no flags set.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_ADD_CONNECTION2_FLAG_TO_DISK
items.desc: to persist the connection to disk.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_ADD_CONNECTION2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY
items.desc: to make the connection in-memory only.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_ADD_CONNECTION2_FLAG_BLOCK_AUTOCONNECT
items.desc: usually, when the connection has autoconnect enabled and gets added, it becomes eligible to autoconnect right away. Setting this flag, disables autoconnect until the connection is manually activated.

title: NMSettingsUpdate2Flags
description: Since: 1.12

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: an alias for numeric zero, no flags set.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_TO_DISK
items.desc: to persist the connection to disk.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY
items.desc: makes the profile in-memory. Note that such profiles are stored in keyfile format under /run. If the file is already in-memory, the file in /run is updated in-place. Otherwise, the previous storage for the profile is left unchanged on disk, and the in-memory copy shadows it. Note that the original filename of the previous persistent storage (if any) is remembered. That means, when later persisting the profile again to disk, the file on disk will be overwritten again. Likewise, when finally deleting the profile, both the storage from /run and persistent storage are deleted (or if the persistent storage does not allow deletion, and nmmeta file is written to mark the UUID as deleted).

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY_DETACHED
items.desc: this is almost the same as %NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY, with one difference: when later deleting the profile, the original profile will not be deleted. Instead a nmmeta file is written to /run to indicate that the profile is gone. Note that if such a nmmeta tombstone file exists and hides a file in persistant storage, then when re-adding the profile with the same UUID, then the original storage is taken over again.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY_ONLY
items.desc: this is like %NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY, but if the connection has a corresponding file on persistent storage, the file will be deleted right away. If the profile is later again persisted to disk, a new, unused filename will be chosen.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_VOLATILE
items.desc: This can be specified with either %NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY, %NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY_DETACHED or %NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_IN_MEMORY_ONLY. After making the connection in-memory only, the connection is marked as volatile. That means, if the connection is currently not active it will be deleted right away. Otherwise, it is marked to for deletion once the connection deactivates. A volatile connection cannot autoactivate again (because it's about to be deleted), but a manual activation will clear the volatile flag.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_BLOCK_AUTOCONNECT
items.desc: usually, when the connection has autoconnect enabled and is modified, it becomes eligible to autoconnect right away. Setting this flag, disables autoconnect until the connection is manually activated.

items.label: NM_SETTINGS_UPDATE2_FLAG_NO_REAPPLY
items.desc: when a profile gets modified that is currently active, then these changes don't take effect for the active device unless the profile gets reactivated or the configuration reapplied. There are two exceptions: by default "connection.zone" and "connection.metered" properties take effect immediately. Specify this flag to prevent these properties to take effect, so that the change is restricted to modify the profile. Since: 1.20.

title: NMTernary
description: An boolean value that can be overridden by a default.

items.label: NM_TERNARY_DEFAULT
items.desc: use the globally-configured default value.

items.label: NM_TERNARY_FALSE
items.desc: the option is disabled.

items.label: NM_TERNARY_TRUE
items.desc: the option is enabled.

title: NMManagerReloadFlags
description: Flags for the manager Reload() call.

items.label: NM_MANAGER_RELOAD_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: an alias for numeric zero, no flags set. This reloads everything that is supported and is identical to a SIGHUP.

items.label: NM_MANAGER_RELOAD_FLAG_CONF
items.desc: reload the NetworkManager.conf configuration from disk. Note that this does not include connections, which can be reloaded via Setting's ReloadConnections().

items.label: NM_MANAGER_RELOAD_FLAG_DNS_RC
items.desc: update DNS configuration, which usually involves writing /etc/resolv.conf anew.

items.label: NM_MANAGER_RELOAD_FLAG_DNS_FULL
items.desc: means to restart the DNS plugin. This is for example useful when using dnsmasq plugin, which uses additional configuration in /etc/NetworkManager/dnsmasq.d. If you edit those files, you can restart the DNS plugin. This action shortly interrupts name resolution.

items.label: NM_MANAGER_RELOAD_FLAG_ALL
items.desc: all flags.

title: NMDeviceInterfaceFlags
description: Flags for a network interface.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_INTERFACE_FLAG_NONE
items.desc: an alias for numeric zero, no flags set.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_INTERFACE_FLAG_UP
items.desc: the interface is enabled from the administrative point of view. Corresponds to kernel IFF_UP.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_INTERFACE_FLAG_LOWER_UP
items.desc: the physical link is up. Corresponds to kernel IFF_LOWER_UP.

items.label: NM_DEVICE_INTERFACE_FLAG_CARRIER
items.desc: the interface has carrier. In most cases this is equal to the value of @NM_DEVICE_INTERFACE_FLAG_LOWER_UP. However some devices have a non-standard carrier detection mechanism.

title: NMClientPermission
description: NMClientPermission values indicate various permissions that NetworkManager clients can obtain to perform certain tasks on behalf of the current user.

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_NONE
items.desc: unknown or no permission

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_ENABLE_DISABLE_NETWORK
items.desc: controls whether networking can be globally enabled or disabled

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_ENABLE_DISABLE_WIFI
items.desc: controls whether Wi-Fi can be globally enabled or disabled

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_ENABLE_DISABLE_WWAN
items.desc: controls whether WWAN (3G) can be globally enabled or disabled

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_ENABLE_DISABLE_WIMAX
items.desc: controls whether WiMAX can be globally enabled or disabled

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_SLEEP_WAKE
items.desc: controls whether the client can ask NetworkManager to sleep and wake

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_NETWORK_CONTROL
items.desc: controls whether networking connections can be started, stopped, and changed

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_WIFI_SHARE_PROTECTED
items.desc: controls whether a password protected Wi-Fi hotspot can be created

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_WIFI_SHARE_OPEN
items.desc: controls whether an open Wi-Fi hotspot can be created

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_SETTINGS_MODIFY_SYSTEM
items.desc: controls whether connections that are available to all users can be modified

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_SETTINGS_MODIFY_OWN
items.desc: controls whether connections owned by the current user can be modified

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_SETTINGS_MODIFY_HOSTNAME
items.desc: controls whether the persistent hostname can be changed

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_SETTINGS_MODIFY_GLOBAL_DNS
items.desc: modify persistent global DNS configuration

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_RELOAD
items.desc: controls access to Reload.

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_CHECKPOINT_ROLLBACK
items.desc: permission to create checkpoints.

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_ENABLE_DISABLE_STATISTICS
items.desc: controls whether device statistics can be globally enabled or disabled

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_ENABLE_DISABLE_CONNECTIVITY_CHECK
items.desc: controls whether connectivity check can be enabled or disabled

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_WIFI_SCAN
items.desc: controls whether wifi scans can be performed

title: NMClientPermissionResult
description: NMClientPermissionResult values indicate what authorizations and permissions the user requires to obtain a given NMClientPermission

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_RESULT_UNKNOWN
items.desc: unknown or no authorization

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_RESULT_YES
items.desc: the permission is available

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_RESULT_AUTH
items.desc: authorization is necessary before the permission is available

items.label: NM_CLIENT_PERMISSION_RESULT_NO
items.desc: permission to perform the operation is denied by system policy
